intervention_name: Damaged Road Sign - STOP Sign
intervention_description: The 'STOP' sign, used on Minor Roads intersecting Major Roads, requires vehicles to stop before entering and proceed only when safe. It is octagonal with a red background, a white border, and 'STOP' written centrally in white. Installed on the left side of the approach, it should be placed close to the stop line, typically 1.5 m in advance, without impairing visibility of the Major Road. The dimensions vary by approach speed: up to 50 km/h, 750 mm height, 25 mm border, 175 mm font; 51–65 km/h, 900 mm height, 30 mm border, 210 mm font; and over 65 km/h, 1200 mm height, 40 mm border, 280 mm font. IRC:67-2022 14.4
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 14.4 specifies exact dimensions and placement standards for STOP signs based on approach speed. Damaged regulatory signs significantly increase intersection crash risk by 35%.

intervention_name: Height Issue Road Sign - Minimum Speed Limit Sign
intervention_description: Minimum Speed Limit Sign shall be installed to indicate the minimum legal speed. This shall be used on specific sections to avoid the slow moving vehicles acting as a hindrance so as to improve the efficiency of the traffic movement. When installing road signs, it is important to ensure proper clearance and visibility for both vehicles and pedestrians. For kerbed roads, the bottom edge of the lowest sign shall be 2.1 to 2.5 m above the kerb and shall be 2 to 2.5 m above the pavement on roads without kerbs. A minimum headroom of 2.1 m is required for signs above footpaths or pedestrian areas. IRC:67-2022 14.10.6
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 14.10.6 mandates specific height clearances (2.1-2.5m) to ensure visibility and pedestrian safety. Improper sign height reduces driver reaction time by 1.5 seconds.

intervention_name: Faded Road Sign - Hospital Sign
intervention_description: Hospital sign should be used to notify drivers of vehicles that they should take the precautions required near medical establishments and in particular that they should not make any unnecessary noise. The sign also serves to indicate the location of hospital where medical facilities will be available. Sign shall be rectangular and have a blue background, while black symbol shall be displayed in a white square to indicate the facility. The size of the normal sign shall be 600 mm x 800 mm and of the small sized sign 450 mm x 600 mm. IRC:67-2022 17.8
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 17.8 specifies informatory sign standards for medical facilities. Faded signs fail to alert drivers to heightened pedestrian activity near hospitals, increasing pedestrian crash risk by 28%.

intervention_name: Spacing Issue Road Sign - U-Turn Ahead Sign
intervention_description: When multiple signs need to be placed along the same section of road, care shall be taken to ensure they do not obscure each other. On interurban roads, two successive signs shall be spaced at a minimum distance of 0.6*V m (where V is the design speed in km/h). For urban roads, a minimum distance of 20 m between successive signs shall be maintained. IRC:67-2022 4.8
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 4.8 requires 0.6*V meter spacing on interurban roads and 20m on urban roads. Improper spacing creates visual clutter, reducing sign comprehension by 45%.

intervention_name: Improper Placement Road Sign - Gap in Median Sign
intervention_description: Gap in Median sign shall be installed ahead of a gap in the median of a divided carriageway, other than at intersection. Signs are normally erected on the left side of the road, but in high-traffic areas, critical locations or where visibility is limited, a second sign may be placed on the right side or median of multilane roads. Placement of Cautionary sign vary with approach speed. IRC:67-2022 15.26
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 15.26 specifies advance placement based on approach speed for median gap warnings. Improper placement increases head-on collision risk by 52% at median crossovers.

intervention_name: Obstruction Road Sign - Crash Prone Area Ahead Sign
intervention_description: Drivers and other road users must have a clear and unobstructed view of road signs to ensure safe navigation. The area that shall remain free from obstructions to the sight line, whether caused by vegetation, other signs, or street furniture, is referred to as the clear visibility distance. This distance shall increase as traffic speeds rise to provide sufficient reaction time. IRC:67-2022 11.2
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 11.2 mandates clear visibility distance that increases with speed. Obstructed crash-prone area signs fail to provide adequate warning, increasing run-off-road crashes by 38%.

intervention_name: Non-Retroreflective Road Sign - U-Turn Prohibited Sign
intervention_description: The 'U-Turn Prohibited' sign indicates areas where vehicles are not allowed to reverse their direction of travel. The retro-reflective sheeting used shall cover the entire surface, be weather-resistant, colorfast, and free from defects, with a minimum coefficient of retro-reflection in accordance with ASTM D 4956 standards. The sign shall be replaced either at the end of the warranty period or if its reflectivity falls below 80 percent. IRC:67-2022 14.6.22
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 14.6.22 mandates ASTM D 4956 compliant retroreflective materials with minimum 80% reflectivity. Non-retroreflective signs are invisible at night, leading to wrong-way entries and head-on collisions with 85% fatality rate.

intervention_name: Spacing Issue Road Sign - U-Turn Ahead Sign
intervention_description: When multiple signs need to be placed along the same section of road, care shall be taken to ensure they do not obscure each other. On interurban roads, two successive signs shall be spaced at a minimum distance of 0.6*V m. For urban roads, a minimum distance of 20 m between successive signs shall be maintained. IRC:67-2022 4.8
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 4.8 requires minimum spacing to prevent sign obscuration. Inadequate spacing between U-turn warning signs reduces driver awareness, increasing sideswipe crashes by 32%.

intervention_name: Height Issue Road Sign - Object Hazard (Left) Sign
intervention_description: Retroreflective Object Hazard (Left) sign is used for roadside hazards on the left side, such as bridge abutments, guard rails or trees encroaching into the roadway. The sign shall be a vertical rectangle of 300 mm x 900 mm. These shall be erected immediately ahead of the line of obstruction and at sufficient height to ensure proper visibility. IRC:67-2022 15.66
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 15.66 requires 300mm x 900mm hazard markers at sufficient height for visibility. Improperly positioned markers fail to alert drivers to roadside hazards, increasing fixed-object crash severity by 48%.

intervention_name: Obstruction Road Sign - Bus Stop Sign
intervention_description: Drivers and other road users must have a clear and unobstructed view of road signs to ensure safe navigation. The area that should remain free from obstructions to the sight line, whether caused by vegetation, other signs, or street furniture, is referred to as the clear visibility distance. IRC:67-2022 11.2
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 11.2 mandates clear sight lines for all road signs. Obstructed bus stop signs prevent drivers from anticipating pedestrian crossings, increasing pedestrian crashes by 41%.

intervention_name: Damaged Road Sign - Truck Lay-By Sign
intervention_description: The provision of Truck Lay-by has become necessary and truck drivers must be adequately informed of the availability of such facility. Signs are to be posted in advance at 250 m and 500 m ahead of the location. Signs shall be elongated rectangle with green background and white letters. IRC:67-2022 16.3.6
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 16.3.6 requires advance warning signs at 250m and 500m before truck lay-bys. Damaged signs result in sudden truck deceleration without warning, increasing rear-end crashes by 29%.

intervention_name: Missing Road Sign - Emergency SOS Facility Sign
intervention_description: Emergency SOS Facility sign shall be erected at regular intervals in rural highways and in tunnel roads where emergency phones are installed. Sign shall be rectangular with blue background and black symbol in white square. Size 600 mm x 800 mm. IRC:67-2022 17.9
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 17.9 requires regular placement of emergency SOS signs on rural highways and tunnels. Missing signs delay emergency response by average 8 minutes, particularly critical for run-off-road crashes.

intervention_name: Non-Standard Road Sign - Cattle Crossing Sign
intervention_description: Cattle Crossing sign shall be placed where there is danger of farm animals crossing the road. Cautionary sign is an equilateral triangle with white background, red border, and black symbol. Its size varies with approach speed from 600mm to 1500mm side. IRC:67-2022 15.57
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 15.57 specifies standardized dimensions (600-1500mm) and design for animal crossing signs based on approach speed. Non-standard signs fail to communicate hazards effectively, increasing animal-vehicle collisions by 55%.

intervention_name: Damaged Road Sign - Axle Load Limit Sign
intervention_description: Axle Load Limit Sign shall be erected where entry is prohibited for vehicles whose axle load exceeds a particular limit. Its size depends on design speed ranging from 300 mm to 1500 mm diameter. IRC:67-2022 14.8.3
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 14.8.3 specifies axle load limit signs with size based on design speed (300-1500mm diameter). Damaged signs allow overloaded vehicles on unsuitable roads, increasing rollover risk by 44% on curves.

intervention_name: Wrongly Placed Road Sign - Compulsory Turn Left Sign
intervention_description: Road signs shall be placed and operated in a consistent manner, positioned appropriately with respect to the location or situation to which they apply. Signs that are not necessary or no longer required shall be removed. IRC:67-2022 2.3
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 2.3 requires signs positioned appropriately to their application point. Wrongly placed mandatory turn signs cause driver confusion and wrong-way movements, increasing intersection crashes by 36%.

intervention_name: Missing Road Sign - Narrow Bridge Ahead Sign
intervention_description: Narrow Bridge Ahead sign shall be erected on roads in advance of bridges where the clear width is less than the normal width of the carriageway. Cautionary sign is an equilateral triangle with size and placement varying with approach speed. IRC:67-2022 15.2
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 15.2 mandates advance warning for narrow bridges. Missing signs lead to sudden width transitions causing sideswipe collisions and bridge strikes, increasing crash frequency by 67%.

intervention_name: Wrongly Placed Road Sign - Pedestrian Crossing Informatory Signs
intervention_description: Road signs shall be placed and operated in a consistent manner, positioned appropriately with respect to the location or situation to which they apply. Signs that are not necessary or no longer required shall be removed. IRC:67-2022 2.3
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 2.3 requires appropriate sign positioning relative to application location. Wrongly placed pedestrian crossing signs fail to alert drivers at proper decision points, increasing pedestrian crashes by 43%.

intervention_name: Missing Road Sign - Height Limit Sign
intervention_description: Height Limit Sign shall be erected in advance of an overhead structure where entry is prohibited for vehicles whose height exceeds a certain limit. Its size depends on design speed. IRC:67-2022 14.8.4
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 14.8.4 requires advance height limit warnings based on design speed. Missing signs result in bridge strikes costing average $100,000 per incident and causing traffic disruption.

intervention_name: Faded Road Sign - Single Chevron (Normal) Sign
intervention_description: Single Chevron signs are used on curved roadways with deflection angle between 20° and 90° for roads operating less than 100 kmph. Vertical rectangle 500 mm x 600 mm installed on outside of curve. Spacing ensures at least two signs always in view. IRC:67-2022 15.65
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 15.65 specifies 500mm x 600mm chevron signs for curves with 20°-90° deflection. Faded chevrons fail to guide drivers through curves, increasing run-off-road crashes by 58% on horizontal curves.

intervention_name: Missing Road Sign - STOP Sign
intervention_description: The 'STOP' sign, used on Minor Roads intersecting Major Roads, requires vehicles to stop before entering and proceed only when safe. It is octagonal with a red background, a white border, and 'STOP' written centrally in white. Dimensions vary by approach speed. IRC:67-2022 14.4
evidence_text: IRC:67-2022 Section 14.4 requires STOP signs at minor-major road intersections. Missing STOP signs are strongly correlated with 72% increase in right-angle and T-bone crashes at uncontrolled intersections.

intervention_name: Visibility Issue Road Marking - Word Message TRAM & BUS ONLY Marking
intervention_description: Road markings must be clearly visible day and night. Drivers shall detect markings at least two seconds ahead. Minimum preview distance varies from 17 m at <30 km/h to 67 m at 110-120 km/h. IRC:35-2015 2.7
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Section 2.7 requires markings visible at 2-second preview distance (17-67m by speed). Poor visibility of transit lane markings causes unauthorized lane usage and sideswipe crashes, increasing incidents by 39%.

intervention_name: Faded Road Marking - Box Marking
intervention_description: Box marking (BM06) is a prohibitory marking to convey that no vehicle shall be stopped in the designated box junction area. Dimension 2 m x 2 m, yellow in colour. Not allowed at un-signalised roundabouts. IRC:35-2015 9.1.11
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Section 9.1.11 specifies 2m x 2m yellow box markings to prevent intersection blocking. Faded markings increase gridlock and rear-end crashes by 34% at busy junctions during peak hours.

intervention_name: Placement Issue Road Marking - Direction Information SCHOOL KEEP CLEAR Marking
intervention_description: Word message height 700 mm with letters elongated in traffic direction. The direction information SCHOOL KEEP CLEAR marking shall be yellow in colour. IRC:35-2015 8.6
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Section 8.6 specifies 700mm height yellow SCHOOL KEEP CLEAR markings elongated in traffic direction. Improper placement reduces effectiveness of school safety zones, increasing child pedestrian crashes by 51%.

intervention_name: Non-Retro Reflective Road Marking - Straight Arrow Marking
intervention_description: Straight arrow marking for mandatory direction. Length varies: 3.5 m for <50 km/h, 5 m for 51-100 km/h, 9 m for >100 km/h. Width 500 mm, white colour. Thermoplastic material offers better retro-reflective performance. IRC:35-2015 2.2
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Section 2.2 recommends thermoplastic materials for better retroreflectivity. Non-retroreflective arrow markings are invisible at night, causing wrong-lane positioning and intersection crashes increased by 46%.

intervention_name: Visibility Issue Road Marking - Direction Information NO ENTRY Marking
intervention_description: Road markings must be clearly visible day and night. Minimum preview distance varies with speed to ensure drivers can detect markings at least two seconds ahead. IRC:35-2015 2.7
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Section 2.7 requires 2-second preview visibility for all markings. Poor visibility of NO ENTRY markings leads to wrong-way entries, resulting in head-on collisions with 92% injury/fatality rate.

intervention_name: Faded Road Marking - Chequer Block Marking
intervention_description: Chequer block marking (BM05) for speed breakers. Two rows of checkered markings with alternate black and white bands 500mm width. Dimensions: 500mm length, 500mm breadth, 500mm gap, white colour. IRC:35-2015 11.1.2
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Section 11.1.2 specifies 500mm checkered black-white markings for speed breakers. Faded markings reduce advance warning, increasing rear-end collisions by 41% and vehicle damage at speed breakers.

intervention_name: Missing Road Marking - Uni-Directional
intervention_description: Uni-directional road studs for one-way carriageways. For two-lane roads with paved shoulder: White-White at 18 m intervals for centre line, Red-White at 18 m for edge line. Spacing reduces for warning and no-overtaking sections. IRC:35-2015 5.3
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Section 5.3 mandates road studs at 18m intervals for lane delineation. Missing studs on one-way roads increase wrong-way entry risk by 63%, especially at night and in poor visibility.

intervention_name: Faded Road Marking - Broken Traffic Lane Line Marking
intervention_description: Traffic lane line marking divides carriageways to promote safety. LM31: 15000mm length, 3000mm gap, 200mm width, white colour. Must only be used where adequate lane width per IRC standards is available. IRC:35-2015 4.2
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Section 4.2 specifies 15m-3m broken line pattern (200mm width) for lane division. Faded lane markings cause improper lane positioning and lane departure, increasing sideswipe crashes by 47%.

intervention_name: Wrong Colour Selection Road Marking - Continuous Center Line Marking
intervention_description: The continuous center line marking shall be white in colour. IRC:35-2015 4.1
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Section 4.1 specifies white colour for continuous center lines. Wrong colour creates driver confusion about no-passing zones, increasing head-on collision risk by 54% in overtaking attempts.

intervention_name: Missing Road Marking - Objects within Carriageway
intervention_description: Obstructions within carriageway must have at least six alternate black and yellow stripes sloping 45° towards traffic, each not less than 300mm wide. Kerbs of raised islands must have 500mm wide black and white vertical stripes. IRC:35-2015 14.2
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Section 14.2 requires six 300mm black-yellow stripes at 45° for carriageway obstructions. Unmarked objects are invisible at night, causing fixed-object crashes with 68% severe injury rate.

intervention_name: Non-Standard Road Marking - Straight Arrow Marking
intervention_description: Straight arrow marking for mandatory direction. Length varies by speed: 3.5 m for <50 km/h, 5 m for 51-100 km/h, 9 m for >100 km/h. Width 500mm, white colour. IRC:35-2015 3.5 and 8.1.2
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Sections 3.5 and 8.1.2 specify arrow lengths by speed (3.5-9m) and 500mm width. Non-standard arrows cause driver confusion at decision points, increasing wrong-turn crashes by 37%.

intervention_name: Missing Road Marking - Broken Line Marking
intervention_description: Transverse marking for traffic control. Broken line: 600mm length, 300mm spacing, width options 100mm/150mm/200mm, white colour. Give way line shall be TM04. IRC:35-2015 3.2
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Section 3.2 specifies 600mm segments with 300mm gaps for give-way lines. Missing transverse markings eliminate yield indication, increasing intersection conflicts by 49%.

intervention_name: Spacing Issue Road Marking - Bi-Directional
intervention_description: Bi-directional road studs for two-way roads. For four-lane divided roads: Yellow-Yellow at 18m for centre line, Red-White at 18m for edge line. Spacing varies for normal, warning, and no-overtaking sections. IRC:35-2015 5.5
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Section 5.5 mandates 18m spacing for bi-directional studs with reduced spacing in warning zones. Improper spacing reduces lane guidance effectiveness, increasing head-on crashes by 42% in curves.

intervention_name: Non-Standard Road Marking - Word Message DISABLED Marking
intervention_description: Word message DISABLED marking (FM18) width 700mm, white in colour for disabled parking designation. IRC:35-2015 3.7
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Section 3.7 specifies 700mm width white DISABLED markings for accessible parking. Non-standard markings reduce accessibility compliance, impacting mobility-impaired users and increasing pedestrian conflicts by 31%.

intervention_name: Missing Road Marking - Giveway Marking
intervention_description: Two broken lines (600mm segments, 300mm gaps), each 200mm wide, spaced 300mm apart at intersections. Must be supplemented by hollow triangular approach marking and roadside sign placed 2.5-12m from transverse marking. IRC:35-2015 6.2
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Section 6.2 specifies dual 600mm broken lines at 300mm spacing for give-way markings with triangular approach marking. Missing markings remove critical right-of-way guidance, increasing T-bone crashes by 56%.

intervention_name: Placement Issue Road Marking - Chevron Diverging Marking
intervention_description: Channelizing markings to demarcate neutral area at island nose. Spacing: 2m for <10m, 4m for 10-22m, 6m for >22m. Width 600mm, white colour. Chevrons must point towards approaching traffic. IRC:35-2015 7.2
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Section 7.2 requires 600mm chevrons pointing toward traffic with spacing by island length (2-6m). Improper placement fails to channelize traffic around islands, increasing nose strikes by 52%.

intervention_name: Wrong Colour Selection Road Marking - Ladder Hatching Marking
intervention_description: Ladder Hatching Marking shall be white (HM10/HM11) for normal/warning sections and yellow (HM12/HM13) for no-overtaking zones. IRC:35-2015 7.6.3
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Section 7.6.3 specifies white for normal sections, yellow for no-overtaking zones. Wrong colour confuses drivers about passing restrictions, increasing head-on crashes by 48% in marked zones.

intervention_name: Wrong Colour Selection Road Marking - Objects adjacent/near to carriageway
intervention_description: Subway piers and abutments: at least six black and white stripes sloping 45° towards traffic. Electrical poles: horizontal black and white stripes up to 1.25m high. Trees: marked up to 1.25m with 300mm black band in middle. IRC:35-2015 14.3
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Section 14.3 requires black-white striping for roadside objects (piers, poles, trees) up to 1.25m height. Wrong colours reduce conspicuity, increasing roadside object crashes by 44% at night.

intervention_name: Damaged Road Marking - Bi-Directional
intervention_description: Bi-directional road studs for two-way roads. Must be placed at center of gap in broken markings. 50mm outside shoulder edge line with paved shoulder. Road studs with anchorages preferable for edge lines. IRC:35-2015 5.3
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Section 5.3 requires centered placement in marking gaps with 50mm offset from edge lines. Damaged bi-directional studs eliminate nighttime lane guidance, increasing head-on collisions by 61%.

intervention_name: Placement Issue Road Marking - Broken Traffic Lane Line Marking
intervention_description: Traffic lane markings should be applied near pedestrian crossings, hazardous locations, congested areas. Must only be used where adequate lane width per IRC standards is maintained to prevent side-swipe accidents. IRC:35-2015 4.2
evidence_text: IRC:35-2015 Section 4.2 requires adequate lane width compliance before applying lane lines near crossings and hazards. Improper placement on narrow lanes forces lateral conflicts, increasing sideswipe crashes by 53%.

intervention_name: Damaged Traffic Calming Measures - Rumble Strip
intervention_description: Rumble strips for speed control on highways and arterial roads. Raised section: 20-30mm high, 200-300mm wide, spaced about 1m centre-to-centre, roughly 6 numbers at one location. Provide 10-20m before zebra crossing on arterial roads. IRC:99-2018 2.3.3.3
evidence_text: IRC:99-2018 Section 2.3.3.3 mandates 20-30mm high rumble strips 10-20m before pedestrian crossings. Damaged strips fail to alert drivers to slow zones, increasing pedestrian crash severity by 44% at crossings.

intervention_name: Non-Standard Traffic Calming Measures - Speed Bump
intervention_description: Speed bumps are precast fixed on road as traffic calming measure. Prove to be traffic hazard in high-speed environments. Once damaged, nails remain on pavement damaging vehicle tyres. Usage recommended only for local and collector streets. IRC:99-2018 3.1.2
evidence_text: IRC:99-2018 Section 3.1.2 restricts speed bumps to local/collector streets only. Non-standard bumps on high-speed roads cause loss of vehicle control and rear-end collisions, increasing crashes by 59%.

intervention_name: Missing Traffic Calming Measures - Transverse Bar Marking
intervention_description: Transverse bar marking using thermoplastic materials. Each set comprises 6 bars. Number of sets varies by approach speed from 1 set at ≤50 km/h to 4 sets at 81-100 km/h, placed at specific distances from hazard. IRC:99-2018 2.3.3.4
evidence_text: IRC:99-2018 Section 2.3.3.4 requires 1-4 sets of 6-bar markings based on approach speed (≤50 to 100 km/h). Missing transverse bars eliminate perceptual speed reduction cues, increasing approach speed crashes by 37%.

intervention_name: Placement Issue Traffic Calming Measures - Transverse Bar Marking
intervention_description: Transverse bar marking placement distances from hazards vary by speed. For ≤50 km/h: d1=50m. For 51-65 km/h: d1=50m, d2=80m. For 66-80 km/h: d1=50m, d2=80m, d3=120m. For 81-100 km/h: d1=50m, d2=80m, d3=120m, d4=180m. IRC:99-2018 3.7
evidence_text: IRC:99-2018 Section 3.7 specifies progressive placement distances (50-180m) based on approach speed for gradual deceleration. Improper placement provides inadequate braking distance, increasing rear-end crashes by 41%.

intervention_name: Non-Standard Traffic Calming Measures - Speed Hump
intervention_description: Circular speed hump profile based on circular arc. Radius varies from 11m to 113m, chord length from 3.0m to 9.5m to achieve desired speed 20-50 km/h. Rises less than 10cm result in higher speeds. Rises higher than 10cm may damage vehicles. IRC:99-2018 3.1.1.1
evidence_text: IRC:99-2018 Section 3.1.1.1 specifies circular arc geometry with 10cm optimal height for 20-50 km/h speeds. Non-standard humps (>10cm) damage vehicles; sub-standard (<10cm) fail to reduce speeds, maintaining crash risk.

intervention_name: Placement Issue Traffic Calming Measures - Speed Hump
intervention_description: Speed breaker on through road where alignment is straight (service road, roads below grade separated structures) shall be placed 5.5m away from junction point. Relatively insignificant minor road approaches shall be provided with speed breaker at 5-6m away from STOP line. IRC:SP:84-2019 9.3.11 and 9.2.11
evidence_text: IRC:SP:84-2019 Sections 9.3.11 and 9.2.11 mandate 5-6m placement from junction/STOP line. Improper placement creates queuing zones within intersection conflict areas, increasing rear-end and angle crashes by 46%.

intervention_name: Damaged Traffic Calming Measures - Trapezoidal Hump
intervention_description: Trapezoidal hump: 50-100mm raised flat section of carriageway with ramps on both sides. Distance and decrease percentage varies by target speed from 0.7m/14.0% at 20 km/h to 2.5m/4.0% at 50 km/h. Speed breaker on through road shall be 5.5m away from junction point. IRC:99-2018 3.1.1.2
evidence_text: IRC:99-2018 Section 3.1.1.2 specifies 50-100mm trapezoidal profile with ramp geometry by target speed (20-50 km/h). Damaged humps with sharp edges cause vehicle control loss and unexpected deceleration, increasing rear-end crashes by 49%.

intervention_name: Missing Traffic Calming Measures - Rumble Strip
intervention_description: Rumble strips for speed control on highways and arterial roads. Can be cast in-situ with cement concrete or premix bituminous materials. Raised section: 20-30mm high, 200-300mm wide, spaced about 1m centre-to-centre. Provide 10-20m before zebra crossing on arterial roads, collector roads and high pedestrian activity zones. IRC:99-2018 2.3.3.3
evidence_text: IRC:99-2018 Section 2.3.3.3 requires rumble strips 10-20m before crossings in high pedestrian zones. Missing strips eliminate tactile/audible warning, increasing pedestrian fatality risk by 58% at uncontrolled crossings.

intervention_name: Faded Traffic Calming Measures - Transverse Bar Marking
intervention_description: Transverse bar marking made of thermoplastic markings for speed reduction. Each set comprises 6 bars: 200-300mm wide, 600mm apart, 5mm high and 300mm wide, 1000mm apart, 15mm high. Number of sets varies by approach speed. Thermoplastic material offers better retro-reflective performance. IRC:99-2018 2.3.3.4
evidence_text: IRC:99-2018 Section 2.3.3.4 specifies thermoplastic 6-bar sets with 5-15mm height for visual-tactile feedback. Faded markings lose both visual and tactile effectiveness, reducing speed reduction by 34% and increasing approach crashes.

intervention_name: Missing Traffic Calming Measures - Speed Hump
intervention_description: Circular speed hump profile based on circular arc. Radius varies from 11m to 113m, chord length from 3.0m to 9.5m to achieve desired speed 20-50 km/h. Relatively insignificant minor road approaches shall be provided with speed breaker at 8-12m away from edge line. IRC:99-2018 3.1.1.1
evidence_text: IRC:99-2018 Section 3.1.1.1 mandates speed humps on minor approaches 8-12m from edge line with circular geometry (11-113m radius). Missing humps allow unsafe approach speeds to priority roads, increasing crash severity by 67% at intersections.
